results.title: The Hindu world
results.brief_description: An historical and cultural survey of Hinduism, set against a background of ancient temples and statues, and Hindu religious rites. Stresses the various mental and physical disciplines called yogas, through which Hindus seek eternal union with Brahma, the universal spirit of God. Also the caste system, the belief in reincarnation and the deep influences of the religion of the Hindu way of life.

results.title: The Hill
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Seven Arts, Kenneth Hyman and Sydney Lumet
results.brief_description: Five British soldiers, all accused of crimes during wartime, are introduced to a prison war camp in Northern Africa during World War II. Run by a tyrannical and old-fashioned Seargent Major (Harry Andrews), the centre of the prison is a man-made “hill” on which the prisoners are routinely punished and tortured. The five new men all represent a cross-section of British society; all find themselves victimised by a sadistic prison guard (played by Ian Hendry) who uses the rhetoric of Empire and Victorian authority to brutalise the men physically and spiritually. When his victimisation goes one step too far, the prisoners must choose between staying silent and winning their freedom, or choosing to support Joe Robert (Sean Connery) who wants to see justice being served. Lumet directs this film with vicious energy, and it is an unrelenting and powerful indictment of the damage that a harsh hierarchical institution can do to men. It’s tough-mindedness and gruelling scenes of punishment and exploitation make it now seem a movie far ahead of its time. Cast also includes Sir Michael Redgrave. Based on a play by Ray Rigby.

results.title: The Highway of steel
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Harold Goodwin and Ralph McCromick
results.brief_description: Emphasises the part played by the British Railways in the production of steel in Great Britain. How iron ore, coke for smelting, and limestone for steel manufacture are transported to the steel works. Follows the production of steel from pig iron to the finished product.

results.title: The Highland heart of Nova Scotia
results.creator_credit: Nova Scotia Information Service, Margaret Perry and Ned Norwood
results.brief_description: Outlines history of Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia highlighting French and Scottish influence on its development. Film depicts traditional music, dancing and crafts and features various places of interest including the Graham Bell Museum, Fort Louisberg, Cabot Trail, etc.

results.title: The Highest court
results.creator_credit: Film Art Doco Pty Ltd, Sue Maslin and Daryl Dellora
results.brief_description: The Highest Court in Australia is an enigma to many. There are sketches of insight which may be attributed to the publicity surrounding cases such as Mabo and Wik, however the mechanisms that have contributed to these decisions are often unknown. This video follows the handing down of two historic judgements; Kruger and Ha, and the appointment of two new Justices. By witnessing these events and processes the viewer is given an informative insight into the High Court and its operation. This documentary is produced by the same individuals who created the title “Mr Neal is entitled to be an agitator” (also in the collection).

results.title: The High: drugs and you
results.brief_description: Three young people give insights into the drug scene - a personable student pusher, a teenager who has graduated from marijuana to speed and freaked out, and another who has tried hard drugs.

results.title: The High wall
results.creator_credit: Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, Columbia Foundation of San Francisco and Michael Road
results.brief_description: Traces a prejudice against immigrants from its beginnings to its development into a socially damaging outburst. In the dramatisation, Tom Gregory’s father, frustrated in his white-collar job, has contaminated his son with the anti-Polish feeling which lets out his repressed hatreds. Tom’s mother also influences the boy with her defensive hostility to different ways of life. Doctors and social workers become involved after Tom’s teenage gang attacks a party in the home of a Polish teenager. The social worker reveals the causes of the teenage riot.

results.title: The High plains
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: The Bogong High Plains contribute to the prosperity of Victoria both as grazing land for cattle and sheep during summer months and as a catchment area for the Kiewa Hydro-Electric Scheme. However, fire, excessive stocking, insect pests and wind have damaged the pastures and soil erosion is now menacing the catchment area. The film outlines methods being used by the Soil Conservation Authority to combat this menace to the State’s hydro-electric projects.

results.title: The High jump
results.brief_description: Analyses the two dominant styles used in world-class high jumping, the Fosbury Flop and the Straddle. Includes aspects of training and exercises relating to the run-up, jump and flight. Written and narrated by Ron Pickering, edited by Peter Delfgou and photographed by Keith Taylor.

results.title: The Hideout
results.brief_description: Portrays two children who face a dilemma when timber belonging to a neighbour is used by another child in building their hideout. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
